Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2009 05:16PM gramadeb wrote: Hi Ellen - I had increasing fatigue after my rads were done. I finished beginning of Aug and by Nov I was so fatigued I could hardly function - I never felt rested. Turns out that I have sleep apnea so was never really sleeping soundly. I now have CPAP and feeling so much better - actually have energy again. Like Deanna said - it may help to look for other causes. Deb
Posts.Title: tired two months later ellen58 LeggyJ

Posts.Content: May 6, 2009 12:12PM gramadeb wrote: Yep, mine fall out every 3 months. I finished chemo one year ago! I heard it does take time for the eyelashes to get into their "normal" cycle again. Fortunately, they grow back quickly! Deb
Posts.Title: LOSING EYELASHES LONG AFTER CHEMO heidiw karla2sassy2

Posts.Content: Apr 21, 2009 09:13PM gramadeb wrote: Hi TheSon, my son was 31 when I was diagnosed. I also have 2 daughters. Each one of them dealt with my diagnosis differently. My son kept me focused on taking one day at a time. He wouldn't let me go to the dark places that are so easy to go to when you are diagnosed with cancer. When he would call or come over he would always tell me he loved me and say "we will get through this". One thing I remember was when I lost my hair - he said "remember Mom, this is only temporary." A simple statement like that really helped keep me looking forward. You are already doing a good thing for your mom by coming to this site. Encourage your mom to visit also. Don't be afraid to ask questions. I also feel that it is OK to let your mom know you are scared and how much she means to you and that you will be there by her side - my children did and it made us all closer because we were on the journey together. Take Care Deb
Posts.Title: Mother Diagnosed TheSon Nicole_Bronx

Posts.Content: Jul 1, 2008 06:06PM gramadeb wrote: I hate that my bald head has a target on top for the mosquitoes to bite. I hate that it took only a few days for my hair to fall out and it takes months for it to grow back It is unfair that I still have to shave my legs. Scarves that twist on my head and make me look like I have been on a 5 day drinking binge. Insurance telling me I have wig coverage only to submit it and then be told that I had a deductible that had to be meet for "durable medical products" - reality - no coverage - wig allowance is $300 and durable medical deductible is $300 - how convenient for them! And I hate my wigs - never wore them. The stare from the 8 year old neighbor boy when I realized I didn't have a headcover on. Being a walking billboard saying "Cancer Patient" People talking to me but avoiding eye contact to avoid the issue. My grandsons initial fear of grandma because she had a scarf on and not hair My 3 year old grandson telling me to put my hat back on!
Posts.Title: What I hate MOST about being bald! HeatherBLocklear dhettish

Posts.Content: Jun 23, 2008 08:49PM gramadeb wrote: HI Sandy, I had a CAT scan before rads - they told me they do a CAT scan to be certain they are radiating the right area and the right depth - so they don't radiate any part of the chest they shouldn't be. Only takes a few minutes. Deb
Posts.Title: CAT Scan before treatmetns begin? easyquilts bcs75

Posts.Content: Jun 16, 2008 02:46PM - edited Jun 16, 2008 02:59PM by gramadeb The hair or lack of it has had me pretty upset the last few days - glad to hear I am not alone. I have no patience to wait for it to grow - I am done with chemo so now I want my hair back! I think I am driving my dh crazy with my obsession! I do have some white fuzzies on top - can feel a little stubble growing. Thin hair on sides and back. My brows are thinning - so far have lashes but after reading your posts I am not hopeful they are going to stay. Hoping that something dramatic will happen and I can throw away the scarves about the same time I finish rads in August! Deb
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Jul 13, 2008 09:47PM gramadeb wrote: Hi Artsee - I can't answer your question, but I can feel your pain. This hair growing process is the pitts because it takes sooo long and we certainly don't need anymore bumps in the road! I am keeping my fingers crossed that it is just a fluke! Deb
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Jul 17, 2008 10:19PM gramadeb wrote: My abnormal hair growth is finally balancing out - left side of my head is covered with gray hair now and a few dark hairs are popping up. Rad nurse today was commenting on my "pretty scarf" and I told her I was so tired of wearing them. She asked how my hair was coming so I showed her and she said it was coming in well and that she thought I could go without my scarf very soon. She said I will look nice with short hair. She probably says that to every post chemo patient - but it was a little ray of sunshine for me today. Eyebrows are filling in but are so light that you can't see them - so sticking with the eyebrow powder. Lost a few lashes earlier in the week but now seem OK. Leg hair growing regularly (of course) - down south is getting fuzzy. Well, there are all the details of my every hairy -or hairless- body part! Artsee - congrats on finishing rads. Take Care Deb
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Aug 11, 2008 10:24PM gramadeb wrote: sandym -my hair initially came in very gray. Now the back is medium brown with little gray. The sides are a darker brown with some gray and the top is white but with dark hair coming in. I have an area on the left top of my head that looks almost black! It is quite a mix of colors. Top hairs are white, but if you look at the scalp it is dark - looks weird - like a shadow under my hair. It is the opposite of getting my hair colored previously - then the roots were gray and the longer hair dark - now roots are dark and longer hair gray! Deb
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Sep 24, 2008 09:40PM gramadeb wrote: Lauren - 4 months after chemo and I love my short curly hair! It is about 1.5 inches long. I had straight hair prior to chemo. I have received so many compliments and people telling me that I should keep my hair this short and how great the color is (white, brown and red!). I love touching it because it is so soft. I agree with you - I feel like I have taken a huge step away from bc and getting back to my old self. Everybody hang in there - losing your hair and then waiting for it to regrow is one of the most difficult things to deal with - but it does come back. Deb
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Jul 12, 2008 09:27PM gramadeb wrote: Is anyone else experiencing their hair growing well in some places and not so well in others? My sides and back are slowly growing - can no longer see my scalp. Crown is feeling thick. On the top of my head - right side is growing well and filling in but the left side is really sparse - looks like someone drew a line right down the middle of my head! I have a hairline on the right but not so much on the left. This is really bumming me out today - haven't felt this low since chemo ended. I think the fatigue from rads is kicking in so that is not helping. I am so tired of having no hair! Deb
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Jul 25, 2008 03:22PM gramadeb wrote: Nancy D - I too have the swirling on top of my head. Today is my "official no more scarves day". My head is covered all over with hair - some dark some gray -front a little thinner than sides and back. But I have had enough of the scarves. Even though my hair is short (really short) I feel good about it and feel a sense of freedom and moving on. A few eyelashes fall out each day - but still maintaining enough to put mascara on and look halfway decent. Take care all - have a good weekend. Deb
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Aug 29, 2008 09:47PM gramadeb wrote: Collector - I am 3 months out from chemo. The hair on the sides continued to grow through chemo. It is thin and wiry compared to the areas where I completely lost my hair and new stuff came in. I have had to trim it a few times because it was so much longer. I don't like the texture of it - thinking I may cut it shorter and see if nicer hair will come in. It was gray for awhile and now it is getting darker.The back and top of my head are very soft and the back has beautiful waves, the sides are straight and weird. My hair did come in gray initially, now the back and side are dark brown, some reddish brown (my original color) and the top is silver with dark color filling in. The top is the only area that has not changed color yet. I am 55 and OK with it - have had many people tell me what a beautiful color it is. Deb
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Sep 25, 2008 09:02PM gramadeb wrote: kerry-lamb - I also had soft fuzz all over my head during chemo - it was very thin. My hair started filling in about 2-3 weeks after chemo. It was slow at first - back filled in quickly, then the sides, then one side of the top of my head. Yes, I looked really funny with hair on half of my head. I stopped wearing scarves (never wore my wig) about 7 weeks after chemo. My hair was about 1/2 inch long and I was very comfortable letting everyone see my very short hair. I made a comment to my co-worker that I probably still looked like a cancer patient with my really short hair and she said  ' no, now you are a cancer survivor"! My hair started getting curly about 8 weeks after chemo. I lost my brows about 5 weeks after chemo. I lost half on each eye - only the brows by my nose stayed so I looked very weird. I now have all my brows but the new ones are so light you cannot see them so I still look weird if I don't use brow powder. I lost my lashes about 6 weeks after chemo, but they grew back very quickly. When your new hair starts growing it will be very soft. I found myself always touching it - felt so could to feel hair on my head again.  It may come in white or gray also. I looked like a cotton ball at first. Then the color started coming in. Still have lots of gray/white but I like it. Hope your last chemo went well. Now you can look forward to new hair growing! Take care Deb
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Oct 21, 2008 10:30PM gramadeb wrote: Chris - I had arm hair throughout chemo and always had a thin fuzz on my head. I had TC also and was never really "bald" You may not lose anything more. Deb
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Jul 6, 2008 09:17PM gramadeb wrote: How weird is this - I actually had to shave my legs today - and I am excited about it! I had a few hairs that hung around through chemo - but today there was enough hair all over my legs to require shaving The hair on my head is gray with very dark strands (salt and pepper) - I have never had dark hair in my life - previously a red head ( with lots of gray over the last few years!). the sides and back are looking pretty good - about 1/2 inch long and covering my scalp. The crown is fuzzy gray and getting thicker. The front is growing good on one side, but not the other - don't like that look. Bald was one thing, but half bald is a little extreme!  Eyelashes hanging in there so far, one clump of eyebrows by my nose on each side and nothing more - haven't really started to grow back yet - bummer! My goal is to ditch the scarves by the time I am done with rads on Aug 7 - hope my hair cooperates! Deb
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Aug 4, 2008 10:50AM gramadeb wrote: Deen - I am 10 weeks out from last chemo and have been going without a scarf or headcovering for one week now -my hair is about the same length as yours. It has been very comfortable for me. My daughters and I went out for dinner on Sat and the waitress told me - "your hair cut is very cute and trendy - but I wouldn't have the guts to shave my head like that"! My daughters started chuckling to themselves. I wanted to tell the waitress that I didn't have the guts either but had no choice - but instead of embarrasing her I just said "just trying something new!" My hair is still a mix of dark brown and gray on sides and back and mostly gray on top. It is getting very thick ( I have always had very thick hair). The back is starting to get wavy. My eyebrows are in but are so light you cannot see them. Eyelashes are slowly returning - at least for now. Take care Deb
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Aug 4, 2008 10:12PM gramadeb wrote: Hi Artsee - no AIs yet. Will start Arimidex in a few weeks. My onc doesn't believe in rads and AI's at the same time because she said if I have se it is too hard to rule out which one is causing the problem. Before chemo my hair was so thick, coarse and heavy I couldn't do much with it. My stylist always told me that she didn't know anyone with hair as thick as mine - so I probably just have lots of hair follicles! Take care Deb
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Aug 11, 2008 12:41PM gramadeb wrote: rockthebald - I don't think it means chemo didn't work - just shows how folks react differently. I shaved my head when my hair first started falling out. Sides and back kept growing during chemo - hair on top would grow between treatments and then fall out. I had to trim my sides last week because they were about 1/2 inch longer than my new growth. I never completely lost all of my hair anywhere - had to shave my legs during chemo etc. My eyebrows got thin and are now growing back but are so light you cannot see them. Lashes didn't start falling out till about 6 weeks after last chemo. They are now growing back and filling in. My hair is filling in pretty nicely and now is starting to get some curl. It is multiple colors - weird. And the top is all growing to the right - making a natural part on the left side of my head. I always parted my hair on the right before chemo. No matter what I do, I cannot get that hair to go any other direction! Deb
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Oct 22, 2008 07:59PM gramadeb wrote: Hi Artsee - good to hear from you again! If you go to page 4 of this thread there are directions on how to post pictures. I never really lost all of my hair with chemo. I always had fuzzy, thin hair on top of my head. A habit that I developed was rubbing that fuzzy hair at night while I was trying to go to sleep. It was some reassurance that I still had some hair! After chemo and when my new hair was coming in I did the same thing because I loved the soft feeling. My DH teases that the reason my hair is curly and thick is that I massaged my hair follicles every night! Now my DH is the one that rubs my hair - he loves the soft curls! Take care Deb

Very easy to take care of. Deb
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Jul 14, 2008 12:56PM gramadeb wrote: I always had some hair stubble and some continued to grow a little during chemo - seemed like it would grow and then fall out with each chemo. Some has stayed and some areas it is about an inch long (sides and back - thin). This area is filling in - the top of my head is really soft - is this the lanugo you are talking about and that will fall out? It seems to be getting thicker - and if I tug it feels secure. Now about 7 weeks out from chemo my eyelashes have decided to take a hike! So I am losing my eyelashes, have one side of my head with hair, the other side still looking bald, eyebrows are very thin. I have been trying to stay positive through this whole cancer thing but I am getting so down over this hair growth - haven't cried for months but am feeling very close to losing it! Deb
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Jul 21, 2008 12:11PM gramadeb wrote: Nancy - duckling down is a great description. My sides and back are long enough to go topless but the white fuzzy duck down scattered over the top of my head is not the most attractive yet. I too have areas where the scalp still shows through. I was going to be brave and post a picture - however the top "duck down" is so white that it didn't even show up in the photo! Could have been the glare on the camera as I didn't pick the best location. Guess I won't be posting my pic! Deb
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Jul 23, 2008 10:15PM gramadeb wrote: I did it - I went to dinner and errands tonight without a scarf! It felt soooo good to go without my scarf. Yesterday I went to see my daughter and her family - hadn't seen them in 5 days. When I walked in their door, both my daughter and son in law said "wow has your hair grown". It was so good to hear those words. I knew it had been filling in and looked better but to hear it from someone elses opinion was huge. The front is a little thinner yet but I officially have a hairline. Today when I went for rads I saw 2 gals with hair the same length as mine. I decided if they can do it, so can I. I didn't get the stares I expected. Not sure I am quite ready to go to work without a scarf - but I guess I will wait to see what tomorrow brings. More of my lashes have decided to leave - just enough left to put some mascara on and feel OK about it. Deb
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Jul 30, 2008 09:49PM gramadeb wrote: I had long hairs too. After my initial head shave, I had hair on the sides and back that grew through chemo. Last week when I decided it was time to ditch the scarves, my dh helped trim some of the 2 inch long hair so I didn't look so wild and crazy. Deen - I had the same experience - taking a shower and realized that more than the hair on my head was growing! So while my head hair and "other" hairs are growing - my eyelashes are becoming as extinct as dinosaurs!
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Sep 3, 2008 09:43PM - edited Sep 4, 2008 09:18PM by gramadeb Hi all - I am 3 1/2 months out from chemo. Hair is 1 inch long and seems to be getting curlier everyday. The back got wavy very quickly but sides and top were just starting to wave. This past weekend, the wave became a more pronounced curl. I was working in the garden and it was very warm outside.When I came in the top of my head was very curly. Thought it was from the humidity and  it would go away after a shower - but it stayed. The sides are frizzy curly, back and top are more wavy and "softer" curling. It's like I have 2 different kinds of hair. When I went back to work on Tues after the long weekend my co-workers could not believe the change. Artsee - mine started with a few waves. I did have some wave in my hair before chemo - but not very much. Those of you waiting for curls - I hope you get a fun surprise and those little hairs start curling real soon! Take Care Deb
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Oct 21, 2008 10:37PM gramadeb wrote: sandym - I had straight hair - would get frizzy in humidity but never curly! I always had very thick hair. I do love the curls and hope they will hang around for awhile. Yes, the hair does come back. Everybody hang in there! Deb
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Aug 25, 2008 09:26PM gramadeb wrote: Karen - I did not lose all lashes - had enough left to put mascara on and look halfway normal. Lashes have returned and actually seem to be longer than before. I always had short lashes so it doesn't take much to make them look longer! Deb
Posts.Title: Taxotere/Cytoxan Lashes/Eyebrows? MsKarin Mocity

Posts.Content: May 15, 2008 09:28PM gramadeb wrote: Hi Mary Jo - I am taking Effexor - initially started for night sweats. It has helped tremendously with the night sweats. I didn't think I was  depressed, but since taking Effexor my mood is definitely better and I feel like I am dealing with all aspects of my life better. I am taking 37.5 mg. One thing I found - you may get mild nausea initially. I take mine at night so I can "sleep" through the nausea. After your body gets used to the Effexor - the nausea goes away - I have no problems now. Hope it works well for you. Deb
Posts.Title: Anyone Had Good Results with Effexor? bluewillow Caya

Posts.Content: May 17, 2008 10:11PM gramadeb wrote: Hi Mary Jo - I was started with "regular" Effexor - made by very nauseated - switched to XR and was better - could tolerate the nausea until my body got used to it. I really do feel better emotionally since starting Effexor - family also says I am doing better. I truly hope you have the same results. It is so important to find some mental relief from everything we are dealing with - get back to enjoying what is important. Take care Deb
Posts.Title: Anyone Had Good Results with Effexor? bluewillow Caya

Posts.Content: Mar 21, 2008 02:40PM gramadeb wrote: I think the pharmacist saw the anguish in my eyes when she told me it wasn't covered. She gave me 4 pills to help me through the weekend so I can be rested to start chemo on Monday - and she didn't make me pay for them! She was my angel today! Gramadeb

I didn't think hair would grow between treatments. It has been11 days since I got round #2 of TC. I still have eyebrows, lashes, body hair etc. I guess I will be disappointed when #2 kicks in and what hair I have left will disappear! Cinlee -  I do the scarves too, can't do the wigs. Posts.Title: Starting chemo in April haykat57 angie27

Posts.Content: Jul 26, 2008 06:16PM gramadeb wrote: Last night was the first time I dreamt about my hair. My dream started with the current length after chemo and right before my eyes it grew about 2 inches so I could style it before I had to go someplace - how weird was that! Of course, it grew in brunette and I was a redhead. Someday it will be 2 inches long. I had short hair to begin with and saw a picture of me from last Nov and I didn't realize just how short my hair was then - so optimistic it won't take me too long to get there again. Deb
Posts.Title: Anyone else dreaming about their hair? NatsFan Jackster51

Posts.Content: Mar 10, 2008 08:02PM gramadeb wrote: Artsee, I am hoping for either low or high - don't want intermediate - don't want to make that decision. I have myself pretty much convinced that I will have a high score. Prior to surgery, docs were all saying radiation and hormone therapy. Right after surgery, the surgeon said I may need a few doses of chemo. Surprised me because she told me the nodes were negative. The next day when she called with the official path report she did say the grade 3 was a concern. At times I think I am prepared for chemo - but I know I am not. I know if my number is high I will panic. But I will do whatever it takes to get rid of any possible cancer cell in my body. Gramadeb

Posts.Title: Oncotype results in artsee artsee

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2008 10:52AM gramadeb wrote: Thanks for your input. I guess I am so stressed out playing the waiting game that I am trying to make plans in my head for what may happen. Like everyone else - just want answers so I can move forward. Newly diagnosed with BC is one thing - waiting to know what the next step is very difficult. Gramadeb
Posts.Title: Oncotype results in artsee artsee

Posts.Content: Nov 5, 2008 12:51PM gramadeb wrote: Denise - TC is very doable! I finished 4 treatments end of May. My onc was very good about treating side effects. I had minimal side effects and felt it was easier than the horror stories I had heard. I worked nearly full time, planted my garden, cleaned my house and spent quality time with my family. Yep, there were days I didn't feel good but I did the best I could. I agree with the positive attitude - a statement that was made to me when I first started this journey - " let yourself have days of feeling sad, worried, nervous, tears etc. but don't let cancer define your life". This was my "motto" during my treatment. I also didn't want to get so wrapped up in my treatment that I was missing the day to day things that were happening. I am now 7 months since diagnosis and sometimes I feel like it has been years. The time does seem to go fast and before you know it you will be looking back and saying "I did it". Hang in there! Deb
Posts.Title: Getting ready to start Taxotere and Cytoxan Onehalf Onehalf

My oncotype results are supposed to be back on 3/17 - the waiting is making me crazy. My gut tells me that due to the grade 3 status that I most likely will have a high score. Can anyone tell me if there is a correlation between grade 3 and Oncotype results?
Posts.Title: Oncotype results in artsee artsee

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2008 11:13AM gramadeb wrote: jpann, Hoping for the 17th - my next appt with oncologist - that will be about 2 weeks since specimen was sent in. My doc says they have been getting results within 2 weeks. If not back by then will reschedule for the 20th. I was doing pretty well for about 10 days - not worrying - waiting for results - but now that it is getting close that is all I think about. From first abnormal mammogram to date of surgery was less than 3 weeks, waiting for this has been about 3 weeks so I am very impatient!!
Posts.Title: Oncotype results in artsee artsee

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2008 12:44PM gramadeb wrote: Jule I do agree with you as far as everything moving so fast in the beginning. I was petrified! In one week I had a screening mamo, diagnostic mamo, ultrasound, biopsies, MRI - I was sure they were not telling me something! I am glad they did push me through the process because it has eased my mind. Now I just need to stop being a worry wart for 6 - 9 days! Did you have chemo? Deb
Posts.Title: Oncotype results in artsee artsee

Posts.Content: Mar 20, 2008 07:28PM gramadeb wrote: My hubby and I had discussed if my oncotype was in the high range of intermediate that I would elect chemo. I want to do everything possible and while I am scared to get chemo I know I did everything I needed to do right from the start. My onc had the same idea! The reason for Taxotere and Cytoxin is less cardiotoxicity and research showing same effectiveness as Adriamycin and Cytoxan. I was given info on Adriamycin but when I heard there was less heart problems with Taxotere I preferred to go with it. Thanks for the reassurance that chemo is not always bad. I know I can do this - now I just want to get it started and not deal with anymore waiting. I am most upset about losing my hair - and having to go back to work with a wig - just feel like I am going to be so uncomfortable. But I think once it happens I will be better and know it is only for a short time. Gramadeb
Posts.Title: Oncotype results in artsee artsee

Posts.Content: Mar 21, 2008 02:21PM gramadeb wrote: I was fortunate to not have to deal with any insurance issues with my chemo (at least none that I am aware of!) - my onc felt pretty strongly about TC as the treatment of choice. Insurance is a frustrating process. No problems covering chemo, all of my diagnostic procedures, surgery etc. But found out today they will not cover my prescription for Lunesta. I haven't slept more than a couple of hours a night since I was dx and finally asked for something and now I can't have it! Well, I can if I pay nearly $200! Gramadeb
Posts.Title: Oncotype results in artsee artsee

Posts.Content: Mar 31, 2008 07:27PM gramadeb wrote: Amy - good luck with your chemo. My first round went much better than I thought. A little tired but no other side effects the first week.  I hated the thought of chemo, but in the long run it will be worth the peace of mind. 1 down - 3 to go! Artsee - how long after chemo did your counts drop? I don't have blood work drawn until just before next chemo in 2 weeks. Deb
Posts.Title: Oncotype results in artsee artsee

Posts.Content: Dec 18, 2008 10:46PM gramadeb wrote: I started Arimidex after chemo and radiation - my onc said she only wanted me to receive one treatment at a time so if there are side effects they know what is causing them. I have been on Arirmidex since Aug and have minimal side effects. Deb
Posts.Title: aromatase inhibitors, the best,with the least side effects?? paras paras

Posts.Content: Apr 25, 2008 12:59PM gramadeb wrote: Angie - I also have problems with constipation right after chemo - and I drink lots of fluids, eat fiber etc. My onc told me to take Mirilax and I did - it was a "gentle" laxative and didn't cause me the cramping that Senokot did. Now this week it is just the opposite - everytime I eat I have to run to the bathroom! Do you feel up to walking or moving about? That helped me on my first round when I couldn't get things going and Senokot was causing me intense cramps. Deb
Posts.Title: Starting chemo in April haykat57 angie27

Posts.Content: Jul 1, 2008 08:22PM gramadeb wrote: I am 5 weeks out from last chemo - my hair is slowly growing back. It is so very soft that I want to constantly touch it! Still impatiently waiting for a real hairline again. Right side of top is growing better than left side. Still very white color but starting to get darker strands - have a 5 o'clock shadow on sides and back. I look like a Q tip on top! I had thick, course, straight hair before chemo - would love to have curls. Your posts are encouraging - I have no patience to wait for my hair to grow back. I guess I will keep touching my soft, fine new hair - in a year I will probably be complaining of having a bad hair day! Deb
Posts.Title: Curly Hair - does it stay or go? Maple Maple

Posts.Content: Sep 17, 2008 07:40PM gramadeb wrote: Amber - yes the 3 smiling faces are my grandsons - love of my life and what has kept me moving forward through this cancer journey. I want to do whatever I can so I can see them grow up and be around for great grandchildren. Kim - I get frustrated when health care professionals think we know everything because we are nurses. I don't volunteer that information and find it is easier. When I had my biopsy I didn't tell them I was a nurse but they soon figured it out because of the questions I was asking.  That worked to my benefit because they knew I understood what was going on and the doc finally was up front and said she was pretty confident it was cancer - I appreciated the honesty. take care Deb
Posts.Title: Nurses with Breast Cancer Jo_Ann_K PatRN10

Posts.Content: Sep 16, 2008 09:18PM gramadeb wrote: Another nurse joining the group! Started nursing career in 1974 - started in critical care. Worked in various ICU's until 1986 when I became a flight nurse for a Level One Trauma Center. In 1994 started working in EMS Education and have been the manager for 10 years. I no longer do patient care so my schedule is pretty flexible. My director has been very supportive during chemo and radiation and was told to take as much time as I needed. I took the week of chemo off, then would work 2 etc. During radiation I worked except for a few Friday's when I was  too fatigued to do anything. I chose to work as much as I could - was a good distraction for me and helped me keep as much of a normal routine as possible. Take Care Deb
Posts.Title: Nurses with Breast Cancer Jo_Ann_K PatRN10
